The present trouble had its origin
in a strike called last Spring .to
protect against wage cuts. These
wage cuts, however, merely came as
a crowning evil to the many already
existing that had led the miners to
the point of revolt.
The same cheating of miners in
the company-owned stores, that was
a point in the previous talk on the
subject, was brought out by the
present speaker. He asserted that
the company stores are twenty to
forty per cent higher than other
institutions. One company, according to his figures, made $13,000
from its store, and only $12,000
from its coal last year.
Right To Organize Contested, Said

The right to unionize is one of
the cardinal points of dispute at
present. Anti-union feeling is very
strong, one operator having fired
thirty-five ·out of seventy-five men
for having union sympathies. Likewise the dishonesty in the weights
credited to the men by the company
was brought out. The speaker
claimed that credit 0n the same
amount of coal has dropped from
43,000 pounds to 3,000 under the
check of the companies. Other
points of contention are the brutalities and slave driving of the miners
by the company guards. In one
case of an eviction a man was
forced to wade a river with his
goods while armed guards stood on
the bridge and laughed. In another
case a man was ordered out of a
cemetery that stood on the companies property by the firm's

Arthur Garfield Hays, reputed
to be one of the country's most
outstanding criminal lawyers, is
scheduled to address the assembly at the Johns Hopkins on
Thursday at 11 :30 A. M. Last
March he appeared at the University for the second time in
three years.
A native . of Rochester, New
York, Mr. Hays received his education in the public schools of
that city, attended the City College of New York, and received
his law <:legree from Columbia
University in 1905.
Was Defense Attorney

Becat1se of his liberality and
his outstanding abilities as an attorney he has achieved nationwide fame. Together ·with Clarence Darrow he was defense attorney for Scopes at the renowned trial held at Dayton,
Tennessee, in 1925.
"The greatest trouble with the
country is that people no longer
have the capacity of indignation,"
it was declared by the criminal
lawyer in his speech "Martyrs of
Injustice," presented at Homewood last March 26.
Charged Juries With Prejudice

In commenting upon the notorious Mary Ware Dennett sexpamphlet case, he charged the
court which convicted her as
typifying the "modern tendency
to cover up and to fear the discussion of the topic." The lawyer also characterized in his
speech the Mooney-Billings case
as "one great frame-up from beginning to end." Sacco and Vcnzetti, he had declared, were
forced to martyrs' deaths because they held views contrary to
those of a prejudiced court.

Approximately $1,250.00 was collected in pledges by the Y. M. C. A.
in its drive for funds last week.
This is an excess of about $50.00
over the amount needed by the
organization. Theodore Stern won
the prize for securing the largest
amount of pledges by obtaining
$1 ro.50, it was announced.
Carroll Hughes, the campaign
leader, considering the present business depression, expressed satisfaction over the reults. The organization which he headed was composed
of four division leaders-Glass,
Mount, Levy and Johnson, each in
charge of the work of three captains, who in turn had three workers
on their teams. The captains were:
Division A-Frey, Pfetzing, Grey;
Division B-DeWolf, Brook, Mulhauser; Division C-Mitchell, C.
Kelly, Weeks, and Division DHendler, Grove, and Packard.
Lockard, Schmeiser, Speak

The campaign was inaugurated at
a dinner meeting of the workers, at
which Bill Schmeiser and Edwin
Lockard were the speakers. Each
day of the campaign, report-luncheons were held, at which the
amounts of the pledges were reported.
The results of this campaign, although satisfactory, were about
$400 short of the total of last year,
w~ich was nearly $1,600. The prize
for individual work went last year
to Gus Burk, who was instrumental
in securing $6oo. '
Cup For Winner Donated

The cup which was given to
Stern for obtaining the largest
amount of pledges was a gift to the
"Y" by Wesley May, a student at
the Medical School. It was presented to the winner by Hughes at
the final report-luncheon Friday.
The pledges obtained by this
campaign to defray a part of the
expense of the Y. M. C. A. at the
University, which are ten times the
amount asked from the students.
The remainder is contributed by
outside persons. The student budget
totaled $1,650, $450 of which is
paid from the funds of the Student
Activities Council.

Budget Includes Levering Upkeep

The student budget, which was
printed ~n the pledge, mainly cares
for the upkeep of certain parts of
Levering, such as furniture repairs,
janitor's supplies, piano tuning, etc.
Still other items were included in
this budget, ranging from handbook
and "Y" News expenses, to freshman and foreign student work.
At the close of the campaign, E.
A. Schaal, secretary of the "Y",
stated that this year the team had
a much harder job than did last
year's, and that they produced as
well as, if not better than, their
predecessors would have under the
same circumstances.

CORRECTION
It was incorrectly stated that Joel
Seidman is president of the Liberal
Club. V. Jackson Lee, however,
holds this office.
The NEWS-LETTER regrets the
error.

Friday night, after the Western Maryland - Hopkins game,
the usual weekly dance will be
held at Levering Hall. The music will be furnished by the
"Ambassadors," an eleven-piece
negro orchestra.
The Cotillon Board has also announced that the Casa Loma orchestra will play at the First
Catillon. The Belvedere Hotel
will be the scene· of the a ff air,
and subscription will be three
dollars per couple.

Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, writer
and bibliographer, will be the guest

from Mr. Hammond, secretary to
the Hopkins Society.
No definite plans for the year
have been announced by the Friends
of the Library, which is an organization of prominent citizens of Baltimore and members of the faculty,
organized for the purpose of maintaining and improving the University library. Further news of interest concerning the society's doings may · be disclosed as soon as
Dr. French, chairman of the society,

EDITORIALS
THE RED CROSS
With the launching of the annual enrollment of members for
the American Red Cross on Armistice Day, November 11, the or·
ganization will mark the fiftieth
anniversary of its founding.
During these fifty years of service, the Red Cross has carried on
untold numbers of humane undertakings.
It has attempted
huge projects in the past and has
always done its job in a complete
and thorough-going manner.
Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University says
of the American Red Cross :
"I do not look for any great,
new, dramatic development in
the program of the Red Cross. I
do not think it needs it. The
superb readiness which it has developed during these last ten
years in the face of emergent
catastrophe, the readiness to act,
and not only the readiness to act
but the ability to act efficiently
--no one can doubt that in the
midst of a National peril, should
it arise, the Red Cross would be
again the expression of a patriotic spirit' which was the finest
thing that was aroused by the
trial through which we passed in
1917."
The Red Cross now has two
functions: it always stands ready
to aid whenever an emergency
arises; and it has a program of
yea~-round useful activities.
"It is, for example, now conducting drought relief in certain
northwestern states, where, except for the magnitude of the
general situation, its operations
would rank as a major effort of
its career.
The northwest
drought project is only dwarfed
by the fact that the Red Cross is
just emerging from a year in
which, besides giving drought relief in 23 states, it extended disaster aid in 52 calamities scattered
through 38 states."
There is also the international
side of the Red Cross movement
which is of great interest for all
Americans. At the close of the
World War and during the time
when peace adjustments were being ironed out, there was found
under the leadership of a group
of Americans, the League of Red
Cross Societies. Through the
formation of this body and the

subsequent operations of the
league, there has developed an
international relationship in the
field of the Red Cross and this
bond is becoming stronger as the
years roll around.
Thus the Red Cross today is
rounding out a half century of
helpfulness and is marching onward with an indomitable spirit
of good will and comfort to the
needy both home and abroad.

"Sometime this fall I will try
to reorganize the German Club of
this University," declared Baron
U. E. von Gienanth, new German
Exchange student in the department of political economy.
Von Ludwiger Fever Victim

One of Baron von Gienanth's
best friends, the late Baron Jurgen von Ludwiger, German Exchange Student who died last
spring of typhoid fever, organized the German Club early last
year; von Gienanth wishes to
carry on the work started by his
friend.
Baron von Gienanth came to
America this fall as a German
exchange student. His home in
Germany was not far from the
Rhine River, near Heidelberg, in
the province of Palatine. He
studied at the University of
Munich in Germany, and received
his degree of Master of Mechanical Engineering there last year.
To Study Political Economy

"\iVhy," he was asked, "did you
choose to study Political Economy?"
"I don't think an engineer
knows enough about the political
organization of his country. I
am studying Political Economy
so that I will know more about
governments. I expect to stay ii1
America until late next summer.
Then I will probably return to
Germany and complete my work
for the degree in Political Economy.
"I feel very fortunate," he
continued, "in being able to at· tend this University. I often
heard Dr. Hollander's (professor
of political economy) name mentioned in Germany. I am very
glad to be studying under him."

The present trouble had its origin
in a strike called last Spring .to
protect against wage cuts. These
wage cuts, however, merely came as
a crowning evil to the many already
existing that had led the miners to
the point of revolt.
The same cheating of miners in
the company-owned stores, that was
a point in the previous talk on the
subject, was brought out by the
present speaker. He asserted that
the company stores are twenty to
forty per cent higher than other
institutions. One company, according to his figures, made $13,000
from its store, and only $12,000
from its coal last year.
Right To Organize Contested, Said

The right to unionize is one of
the cardinal points of dispute at
present. Anti-union feeling is very
strong, one operator having fired
thirty-five ·out of seventy-five men
for having union sympathies. Likewise the dishonesty in the weights
credited to the men by the company
was brought out. The speaker
claimed that credit 0n the same
amount of coal has dropped from
43,000 pounds to 3,000 under the
check of the companies. Other
points of contention are the brutalities and slave driving of the miners

Arthur Garfield Hays, reputed
to be one of the country's most
outstanding criminal lawyers, is
scheduled to address the assembly at the Johns Hopkins on
Thursday at 11 :30 A. M. Last
March he appeared at the University for the second time in
three years.
A native . of Rochester, New
York, Mr. Hays received his education in the public schools of
that city, attended the City College of New York, and received
his law <:legree from Columbia
University in 1905.
Was Defense Attorney

Becat1se of his liberality and
his outstanding abilities as an attorney he has achieved nationwide fame. Together ·with Clarence Darrow he was defense attorney for Scopes at the renowned trial held at Dayton,
Tennessee, in 1925.
"The greatest trouble with the
country is that people no longer
have the capacity of indignation,"
it was declared by the criminal
lawyer in his speech "Martyrs of
Injustice," presented at Homewood last March 26.
Charged Juries With Prejudice

In commenting upon the notorious Mary Ware Dennett sexpamphlet case, he charged the
court which convicted her as
typifying the "modern tendency
to cover up and to fear the discussion of the topic." The lawyer also characterized in his
speech the Mooney-Billings case
as "one great frame-up from beginning to end." Sacco and Vcnzetti, he had declared, were
forced to martyrs' deaths because they held views contrary to
those of a prejudiced court.

Approximately $1,250.00 was collected in pledges by the Y. M. C. A.
in its drive for funds last week.
This is an excess of about $50.00
over the amount needed by the
organization. Theodore Stern won
the prize for securing the largest
amount of pledges by obtaining
$1 ro.50, it was announced.
Carroll Hughes, the campaign
leader, considering the present business depression, expressed satisfaction over the reults. The organization which he headed was composed
of four division leaders-Glass,
Mount, Levy and Johnson, each in
charge of the work of three captains, who in turn had three workers
on their teams. The captains were:
Division A-Frey, Pfetzing, Grey;
Division B-DeWolf, Brook, Mulhauser; Division C-Mitchell, C.
Kelly, Weeks, and Division DHendler, Grove, and Packard.
Lockard, Schmeiser, Speak

The campaign was inaugurated at
a dinner meeting of the workers, at
which Bill Schmeiser and Edwin
Lockard were the speakers. Each
day of the campaign, report-luncheons were held, at which the
amounts of the pledges were reported.
The results of this campaign, although satisfactory, were about
$400 short of the total of last year,
w~ich was nearly $1,600. The prize
for individual work went last year
to Gus Burk, who was instrumental
in securing $6oo. '
Cup For Winner Donated

The cup which was given to
Stern for obtaining the largest
amount of pledges was a gift to the
"Y" by Wesley May, a student at
the Medical School. It was presented to the winner by Hughes at
the final report-luncheon Friday.
The pledges obtained by this
campaign to defray a part of the
expense of the Y. M. C. A. at the
University, which are ten times the
amount asked from the students.
The remainder is contributed by
outside persons. The student budget
totaled $1,650, $450 of which is
paid from the funds of the Student
Activities Council.

Budget Includes Levering Upkeep

The student budget, which was
printed ~n the pledge, mainly cares
for the upkeep of certain parts of
Levering, such as furniture repairs,
janitor's supplies, piano tuning, etc.
Still other items were included in
this budget, ranging from handbook
and "Y" News expenses, to freshman and foreign student work.
At the close of the campaign, E.
A. Schaal, secretary of the "Y",
stated that this year the team had
a much harder job than did last
year's, and that they produced as
well as, if not better than, their
predecessors would have under the
same circumstances.

EDITORIALS
THE RED CROSS
With the launching of the annual enrollment of members for
the American Red Cross on Armistice Day, November 11, the or·
ganization will mark the fiftieth
anniversary of its founding.
During these fifty years of service, the Red Cross has carried on
untold numbers of humane undertakings.
It has attempted
huge projects in the past and has
always done its job in a complete
and thorough-going manner.
Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University says
of the American Red Cross :
"I do not look for any great,
new, dramatic development in
the program of the Red Cross. I
do not think it needs it. The
superb readiness which it has developed during these last ten
years in the face of emergent
catastrophe, the readiness to act,
and not only the readiness to act
but the ability to act efficiently
--no one can doubt that in the
midst of a National peril, should
it arise, the Red Cross would be
again the expression of a patriotic spirit' which was the finest
thing that was aroused by the
trial through which we passed in
1917."
The Red Cross now has two
functions: it always stands ready
to aid whenever an emergency
arises; and it has a program of
yea~-round useful activities.
"It is, for example, now conducting drought relief in certain
northwestern states, where, except for the magnitude of the
general situation, its operations
would rank as a major effort of
its career.
The northwest
drought project is only dwarfed
by the fact that the Red Cross is
just emerging from a year in
which, besides giving drought relief in 23 states, it extended disaster aid in 52 calamities scattered
through 38 states."
There is also the international
side of the Red Cross movement
which is of great interest for all
Americans. At the close of the
World War and during the time
when peace adjustments were being ironed out, there was found
under the leadership of a group
of Americans, the League of Red
Cross Societies. Through the
formation of this body and the

subsequent operations of the
league, there has developed an
international relationship in the
field of the Red Cross and this
bond is becoming stronger as the
years roll around.
Thus the Red Cross today is
rounding out a half century of
helpfulness and is marching onward with an indomitable spirit
of good will and comfort to the
needy both home and abroad.

"Sometime this fall I will try
to reorganize the German Club of
this University," declared Baron
U. E. von Gienanth, new German
Exchange student in the department of political economy.
Von Ludwiger Fever Victim

One of Baron von Gienanth's
best friends, the late Baron Jurgen von Ludwiger, German Exchange Student who died last
spring of typhoid fever, organized the German Club early last
year; von Gienanth wishes to
carry on the work started by his
friend.
Baron von Gienanth came to
America this fall as a German
exchange student. His home in
Germany was not far from the
Rhine River, near Heidelberg, in
the province of Palatine. He
studied at the University of
Munich in Germany, and received
his degree of Master of Mechanical Engineering there last year.
To Study Political Economy

"\iVhy," he was asked, "did you
choose to study Political Economy?"
"I don't think an engineer
knows enough about the political
organization of his country. I
am studying Political Economy
so that I will know more about
governments. I expect to stay ii1
America until late next summer.
Then I will probably return to
Germany and complete my work
for the degree in Political Economy.
"I feel very fortunate," he
continued, "in being able to at· tend this University. I often
heard Dr. Hollander's (professor
of political economy) name mentioned in Germany. I am very
glad to be studying under him."

At the invitation of the Governing Board of the Tudor and Stuart
Club, the English Journal Club will
hold its first meeting in the Tudor
and Stuart Clubroom, Room 303,
Gilman Hall at 3 o'clock today.
For the first hour the Journal
Club will discuss the recent developments in English literature. Articles
that recently have appeared in the
scholarly journals will be reviewed.
The remainder of the meeting will
be concerned essentially in acquainting graduate students aTid the faculty with each other. All the members of the club and the graduate
students in English are invited.
